posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Last year we ran python scripts on a Jetson Nano that used networktables and cscore. Unfortunately, Jetson Nano runs Ubuntu 18.04. I started upgrading these scripts for 2023, but I’m not able to install the needed python modules. I assume this is because WPILib now requires Ubunto 22.04+. Any ideas?

Additional info… last year we used pynetworktables , but it looks like we should now use pyntcore . Here’s the output from installing pyntcore :

Here’s the output from installing cscore , it’s the same error:

The Jetson is running Python 3.6, but it could probably be upgraded. 3.8 seems to be the latest “supported” version, but I might be able to go newer.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Here are some more things I tried. I ran pip3 install robotpy_build and it was successful. After that, pip3 install pyntcore got a lot further but it still failed.

Next I tried upgrading to python 3.8.

Now I was successful at installing robotpy_build . However, when I tried to install pyntcore I got errors about wpiutil .

I think I’m be blocked now since I can’t update Ubuntu.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Are you able to install a newer GCC (11 or later)? GitHub - wpilibsuite/allwpilib: Official Repository of WPILibJ and WPILibC

link_counts.title: GitHub - wpilibsuite/allwpilib: Official Repository of WPILibJ and WPILibC

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: I think it’s running gcc 7.5. Unfortunately, I don’t know how to install a newer version.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
OK, I managed to get gcc 11 installed, but I’m not sure if this is the “right” way. I don’t know if ppa:ubuntu-toolchain-r/test is the right repository to use, but it worked.

I installed it with these commands:

I set the tools to be the default alternatives with these commands:

It looks like it’s set up:

Now I get this error trying to install robotpy_wpiutil .

Which is fair, the WPILib docs do say glibc >= 2.32 is required. I don’t think there is a safe way to upgrade glibc.

link_counts.title: New for 2023 — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Davo
posts.cooked:
Are you able to upgrade your Jetson Nano to Ubuntu 22.04?

If not, you can still use robotpy-cscore from last year. 2023 ntcore is backwards compatible with the NT3 protocol that pynetworktables implements.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: I’m going to try upgrading Ubuntu, but I’m not expecting it to work. That’s good to know that it’s still compatible with last year. My fallback will be run all 2022 on the Jetson.

posts.cooked:

I’ve been away from home all week, so I haven’t had time to update the documentation.

[edit: it’s likely that the prebuilt wheels will require Ubuntu 22.04 since that’s what WPILib requires]

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: Using last year’s libraries worked. I’ll post this in case someone else finds themself looking for the solution:

posts.name: Puzzle
posts.cooked: Hey, we’ve run into the same problem. We are unable to install pyntcore and cscore on the jetson. Also, we ran our scripts and send data over pynetworktables but it randomly freezes a lot. Sometimes data is updated quickly and suddenly it freezes for a long period of time. Is this because we are using pynetworktables instead of pyntcore? How can we install Ubuntu 22.04 on the Jetson?

posts.name: Banks T
posts.cooked: You cannot. The Jetson Nano will not receive any Jetpack updates past 4.6.1, which is Ubuntu 18.04. It is effectively end-of-life.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Dumb question, could you run a docker container in 22.04 on the Jetson?

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Puzzled:

we ran our scripts and send data over pynetworktables but it randomly freezes a lot

I have not run into this problem. Maybe start a new topic and ask for help with your script.

thatmattguy:

Dumb question, could you run a docker container in 22.04 on the Jetson?

Good thought. It does run Docker, but I’m sure it would not be easy to get CUDA to work in a 22.04 container. Without GPU access, it’s just an overpriced RPi.

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
Puzzled:

Also, we ran our scripts and send data over pynetworktables but it randomly freezes a lot

pynetworktables has been around for many years at this point, so it’s likely a problem with your script (or maaaayyybe it’s an NT3 incompatibility that NT4 has). If you don’t think so, feel free to file a bug on github and we can discuss.

posts.name: Aron Rubin
posts.cooked:
FYI I believe it is possible to run a fully functional Ubuntu 22 in a container running on the jetson.

Edit: @thatmattguy sorry i didn’t see you saying the same.

posts.custom_user_title: Maker, Mild-Tempered Scientist, Overly Seasoned Engineer

posts.name: Davo
posts.cooked:
If anyone is struggling to build an old robotpy-cscore, my packages on the OpenSUSE Build Service are still available for Ubuntu 18.04 ARM, as it turns out.

You’ll want the python3-cscore binary package. If downloading manually for offline install, grab python3-networktables too.

Keep in mind that this currently has robotpy-cscore 2021 rather than 2022. If anyone particularly needs a 2022 version then I could upload a new version.
Nvidia does have a docker image built for leveraging the gpu.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked: Yes, but not with 22.04. That’s the whole problem.
